content.webTitle: Cymru am byth: Cardiff fanzone roars after historic Wales victory

fields.headline: Cymru am byth: Cardiff fanzone roars after historic Wales victory
fields.bodyText: Throughout the game they sang, they chanted, they screamed, they yelled. And then, at final whistle, the Welsh fans hugged and kissed. In a heaving, passionate fanzone in Cardiff, grown men and women wept openly while children laughed with joy as they celebrated one of the greatest sporting triumphs in their nation’s history. Whatever happens next – and who now would bet against Wales reaching the final? A country more famous for its brave exploits with the oval ball than the round one will remember forever a group of players that exemplified teamwork, industry and pride. The Welsh FA’s campaign tagline, Together Stronger, was well chosen. “It’s just wonderful,” said Simon Edmunds, from the seaside town of Barry, who watched the 3-1 win against Belgium. “This team has done us proud and brought the nation closer. Wales is traditionally a rugby nation – in my lifetime football has always been second best. This changes that. We’ve waited so long for it.” Indeed it has. The nation that counts John Charles, Ian Rush and Ryan Giggs among its great footballers had gone more than half a century without this sort of success. Wales had not reached a major championship at all since 1958, when they lost 1-0 in the quarter finals to Brazil – thanks to a first-ever World Cup goal for Pelé. The success of Gareth Bale and his teammates in Friday night’s Euro 2016 quarter-final means that old disappointments can finally be put behind them. Semi-final opponents Portugal should beware. The excitement in Wales had grown during the day. Across the country, schoolchildren, bank staff, and office workers had exchanged their uniforms and suits for red Welsh tops. Tattoo parlours reported a brisk business in dragon motifs, butchers in lamb chops and shoulders as barbecues were fired up. Companies that employ nightshift workers had set up giant screens in the hope of encouraging staff not to pick up a convenient migraine or touch of summer cold. Radio stations had torn up their usual playlists to blare out Welsh favourites from Manic Street Preachers to Shirley Bassey and Catatonia – whose 1990s bilingual song International Velvet, featuring the lyrics “Everyday when I wake up/I thank the Lord I’m Welsh”, had a particular resonance on this of all days. Some of those in the fanzone in Cardiff had travelled from far and wide, keen to stand shoulder to shoulder with their countrymen and women. “I wouldn’t have been anywhere else tonight,” said Steve Bay, a builder from Brecon, who was sporting a woolly sheep hat. “I’m proud to be Welsh, proud to be part of this. That’s the thing – this team has made us feel part of something. I’ll never forget them for that.” The extraordinary thing about the mood in the fan zone, just behind Cardiff castle, was that it was always joyful, never nervous. When the goals went in and the beer was thrown high into the air, it was done with a sense of pure happiness, not relief. It felt like they always knew. Jill Jones, an accountant based in the US, had taken time off to jet back into Cardiff so that she could watch the game with her mates. “Honestly, it’s been great,” she beamed. “At times like this you need to be with your nearest and dearest. This is one of the best days of my life. We’re a small nation – just 3 million people. But when you work together anything is possible.” Many of those in the fanzone were not old enough to remember the 1958 tournament and have endured years of torment as Wales so often fell short. Others, like eight-year-old Stan – who was playing football with his mates in a corner of the beer-soaked field, has only good memories of Wales. “We’re the best in the world,” he said. “Bale’s the best footballer in the world. He’ll get Cristiano Ronaldo, no problem.” There are already some striking statues in Cardiff – the architect of the NHS, Nye Bevan, musician Ivor Novello and rugby star Gareth Edwards to name but three. There will surely be a clamour now for a statue to commemorate the exploits of this team. Bill O’Keefe, who takes visitors on guided tours of the Welsh capital, had spent the day talking football to his clients as well as history. He had been telling German visitors that Wales would see them in the final. “They’ll be putting up statues of this team now, naming roads after the manager,” he said. “It’s got to be Sir Gareth [Bale], hasn’t it?”
